overview: A Universally Unique Identifier (UUID) is a 128-bit number used as a unique identifier.
aboutUuid1: UUID v1 is pseudorandom, created using the time of creation and the MAC address of the computer that created it.
aboutUuid3: UUID v3 is an MD5 hash, created using a namespace and a name. The namespace must be a UUID, and the name can be any string. Given the same namespace and name, you will always get the same UUID.
aboutUuid4: UUID v4 is random or pseudorandom, depending on how it is generated. The version 4 UUIDs produced by this tool are cryptographically-strong random values.
aboutUuid5: UUID v5 is a SHA-1 hash, created using a namespace and a name. Much like v3 UUIDs, given the same namespace and name, you will always get the same UUID. The namespace for v5 UUIDs can either be a UUID, or a preset namespace type (URL, DNS, ISO OID, and X.500 DN), this tool does not currently support ISO OID or X.500 DN.
